sentences.text: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures .
The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words .
Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented .
Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words .
Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics .
Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs .
The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

kg2text: This poster paper presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of Turkish word structures and morphological constructions. It describes a full scale two-level morphological description that is based on a root word lexicon containing approximately 23,000 root words. Turkish word structures, which are surface realizations of morphological constructions, are characteristic of the agglutinative nature of the Turkish language. The PC-KIMMO environment, which has been implemented using PC-KIMMO, utilizes this root word lexicon to analyze and generate morphological descriptions. Furthermore, the surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by phonetic rules, while derivational and inflectional suffixes play a crucial role in the formation of words, allowing root words to convert into various grammatical structures, including verbal and nominal forms.

In the study of Turkish morphology, derivational and inflectional suffixes are recognized as a subset of morphemes, which are fundamental units that can be added to a stem to form new words. These morphemes play a crucial role in converting root words into various grammatical forms, thereby facilitating the creation of adverbial constructs. However, there are special cases that serve as exceptions to the established morphological rules, which are systematically described in the morphological description of the language. These exceptions are also categorized under a broader term known as exceptions. Additionally, inflectional suffixes, which are a type of morpheme, further illustrate the complexity of morphological rules. The finite-state model is another broader concept that encompasses these morphological descriptions, particularly in the context of Turkish. Phonetic rules, including phenomena such as vowel harmony, govern the pronunciation of words and are integral to understanding the phonological aspects of the language.
